fs.f: k → affrication (in the environment of anterior vowel) /ć/
k → affrication (in the environment of anterior vowel) /č/

revisionDesc.change: Added nav link goto:{@xml:id} to XSLT. This allows to navigate from XSLT to XML editor.
Added visualisation of examples to XSLT
Made xPath (elementPath) for feature selection generic, added "contains": //tei:fvLib[contains(@xml:id,'_values')]/tei:fs
Added @xml:id on featureRealisation: this is needed to navigate in HTML output
reworked example: * proposed renaming of "occurence" to "featureRealisation" * made
reworked examples based on last meeting: * tentatively added f[@name="explanation"] to featureValues

list.item: Repair realisationType: fVal needs to be xml:id

div.p: Uvular realisation is preserved in MSA loanwords, ex. taqrīban «approximately», qarīban «soon» and in some Turkish loanwords, ex. qawūn «melon» and by young speakers often in words realized with /g/ or /ǧ/ by older speakers, ex. gidīm or ǧidim - qadīm «old», gilīl or ǧilīl - qalīl «few, little» ; Devoicing of /g/ to /k/ in contact with /t/, ex. k-t-l (which sometimes becomes affricated in the environment of an anterior vowel c-t-l)

f.name: note
f.string: Exception: čān - yikūn; there is desaffrication when in contact with coronal consonants [d], [t], [ḏ], [t],̱ [t]̣ et [ḏ̣ ]

f.name: note
f.string: čān - yikūn; ʾabū-k «ton père (m.)» et ʾabū-č«ton père (f.); [k] is reestablished in the passive participles of verbs C-C-k of scheme *maC1C2ūC3 (ex. manyūk, maʿlūk et mahlūk)

f.name: note
f.string: vestigial variants: čīl "measure, weight", yčammilen "they (f.) complete", čänna "daughter in law", etc.

f.name: note
f.string: k to x: lexically restricted spirantization: xtar 'more', but not *xtir, but ktir 'much'

f.name: note
f.string: /k/ in Kormakiti has the palatal and veralallophonic variants /k'/ and /k/ before front and non-front vowels respectively

f.name: note
f.string: Exception:the pronominal suffix of the second person singular feminine may be an affricate č (as noted in Poesies Fezzanaises)

f.name: note
f.string: There was nothing concrete about the reflex of /k/ in the chapter regarding al-Khums, but in the examples /k/ is always reflected as it is

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard and all have a minimal pair showing phonemic opposition bētuḳ “your (sg. masc.) house” – bētik “your (sg. Fem.) house”

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard, true phonemic opposition in a minimal pair īduḳ “your (sg. masc.) hand” – īdik “your (sg. fem.) hand”

f.name: note
f.string: ḳ and k are heard, a true phonemic opposition seams to be developing

f.name: note
f.string: /k/ is realized as the affricate [č] in contact with /i/ by some speakers, probably due to influence from the Eastern part of the peninsula

f.name: note
f.string: affrication seems to be at least partly lexically conditioned, as in čānūn, "portable hearth"

f.name: note
f.string: note that Young did not transcribe from recordings, but by ear

cit.note: With regards to the example, the /l/ 'is assimilated to a following /k/ in bikkill - bilkill (with vowel harmony). This is a recent change as previous dialectologists do not record this assimilation in the same word
